title-group.article-title: Association between oral microbiome diversity and all-cause mortality: a longitudinal study of NHANES, 2009–2012

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Thyroid Surgery, The First Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The study investigates the association between oral microbiome diversity and all-cause mortality.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Population-based cohort study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (2009–2010 and 2011–2012).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 8224 participants who had valid data on the oral microbiome diversity and survival through 31 December 2019 were included in this study.

sec.title: Primary and secondary outcome measures
sec.p: Oral microbiome diversity was measured using the observed number of amplicon sequence variant (ASV) and grouped into quartiles. Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to estimate the HR and 95% CI for all-cause mortality according to the quartiles of ASV number, adjusted for potential confounders.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Among the 8224 participants (mean (SD) age: 42.0 (15.1) years; 49.9% male; 37.2% white, 23.8% black, 27.2% Hispanic and 11.8% other race/ethnicity), the median follow-up time was 108 months (IQR, 95–120 months) and 429 (5.2%) deaths were identified. Participants with a higher ASV number were more likely to be poor, non-Hispanic black or Hispanic, uninsured and current smokers, more likely to have poor self-rated oral health and periodontitis and less likely to use dental floss. However, compared with the lowest quartile of the ASV number, a suggestive association was observed for the second quartile (HR=0.80, 95% CI: 0.60 to 1.08), a significant reduction in all-cause mortality was observed for the third (HR=0.55, 95% CI: 0.37 to 0.82) and the fourth (HR=0.58, 95% CI: 0.38 to 0.89) quartile. The dose–response association for all-cause mortality risk was curvilinear; the protective association plateaued when the number of ASVs was larger than 120.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite being linked to greater socioeconomic disadvantages and poorer oral health, higher oral microbiome diversity was significantly associated with a substantial reduction in all-cause mortality.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China

caption.title: Strengths and limitations of this study

list-item.p: It is a large-scale, nationwide, population-based study.
Our study effectively explores the relationship between oral microbiome diversity and various characteristics such as socioeconomic status, general health status and oral health variables.
There might be some bias because the definitions of socioeconomic status and medical history were obtained from self-reports.
Oral microbiome data are collected at a single point in time, which makes it impossible to study how microbiome diversity changes over time and how these changes affect individual health.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Oral health is important and closely related to the overall well-being.15 Clinical evidence has established strong associations between oral diseases and systemic conditions, including cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, pulmonary diseases, pregnancy complications, dementia and mental health.69 Recognising the importance of oral health, various oral hygiene practices, such as flossing and mouthwash usage, have been widely recommended to enhance oral health in the general population.1014 In addition to effectively preventing oral diseases,1014 these hygienic practices also bring about substantial changes to the oral microbiome due to their antimicrobial properties. Notably, studies have found that flossing and mouthwash usage reduced oral microbiome diversity,15 16 while a higher oral microbiome diversity is typically associated with poorer oral health.17

On the other hand, the human oral microbiome serves multiple vital functions in maintaining human health.18 As it resides in the beginning of the human digestive tract, the oral microbiome is involved in regulating nutrient absorption, substance metabolism, immune responses and other related physiological activities.19 Beyond its role in oral diseases, recent research has revealed connections between alterations in the oral microbiome and diverse diseases or conditions, including cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, hyperglycaemia and obesity.2024 These emerging findings have garnered attention to the health implications of the oral microbiome.25

Our understanding of the relationship between the oral microbiome and human health remains limited. Many studies investigating the oral microbiome have relied on convenience samples of restricted size or have been conducted within experimental settings.26 The clinical importance of the oral microbiome at the population level has been understudied, warranting more investigations. The recent release of oral microbiome data from the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2009–2012 presents an opportunity to assess how the oral microbiome influences the health of individuals within a large and diverse population.26 Leveraging on these nationally representative population data, we conducted this study to estimate the association between oral microbiome diversity and all-cause mortality through the end of 2019.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The present study used two NHANES waves of 2009–2010 and 2011–2012 that measured the oral microbiome. The NHANES oral microbiome data reflect the overall demographic diversity of the US population, including race, ethnicity and education within the 14–69 years age group (online supplemental method S1).2729 A flow chart for participant selection can be found in figure 1.

caption.title: Flow chart of participants selection. NHANES, National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.

sec.title: Oral microbiome measure
sec.p: Oral microbiome testing was performed using oral rinse samples that were originally collected to study the prevalence of oral human papillomavirus in the US population. Results from the oral microbiome testing included classification of microbial sequences into amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) which were used to generate diversity matrices used in this study. The method for DNA extraction, bioinformatic procedures and related codes can be found in previous NHANES publications.30

The alpha diversity is a measurement of the microbiome diversity within a single participant, typically representing community richness and community evenness. The study focused on the observed number of ASVs, a simple measure of alpha diversity that represents the number of unique microbial taxa detected for each participant. This metric is commonly used to compare the richness of different samples or to investigate changes in diversity between exposure groups. NHANES provided two ASV feature tables and we used the one that keeps all taxa. The observed number of ASVs appeared to reach saturation by a rarefaction value of 10 000,26 and this saturated number was analysed. The distribution of the observed number of ASVs is presented in figure 2.

caption.title: Distribution of the observed number of ASVs in the overall study population, NHANES 2009–2012. NHANES, National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.

sec.title: Mortality ascertainment
sec.p: NCHS mortality was determined using a probabilistic record match between NHANES participants and National Death Index (NDI) death certificate data. The NHANES-linked NDI public access data through 31 December 2019 was analysed in this study.31 Details on covariates are described in online supplemental methods S2 and S3.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The observed number of ASVs was grouped into quartiles, as a lower quartile indicated a lower number of ASVs. Differences in the overall survival between observed ASV quartiles were visualised via the Kaplan-Meier plot (figure 3).

caption.title: Kaplan-Meier curve for overall survival according to the quartiles of the ASV number in the overall study population, NHANES 2009–2012. NHANES, National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.

sec.p: We applied Cox proportional hazards regression to estimate HRs and 95% CIs for the associations between observed ASV quartiles and overall survival. Three different models were considered. Model 1 adjusted for basic demographic covariates, including age, race/ethnicity and gender. No missing values were reported in these three variables. Model 2 additionally adjusted for socioeconomic and health-related covariates, including income-poverty ratio, health insurance status, body mass index (BMI), smoking status, cancer history, hypertension, diabetes and self-rated general health. Model 3 further adjusted for oral health-related covariates, including self-reported oral health and periodontitis, in addition to covariates in model 2. We also performed stratified analysis by age (<50 vs ≥50) to assess patterns of associations by age. The first quartile (ie, the group with the lowest number of ASVs) was treated as the reference group in the regression models.

To investigate the potential nonlinearity and thresholds for estimated risks associated with the oral microbiome diversity, we used restricted cubic spline functions with 4 evenly distributed knots (at the 20th, 40th, 60th and 80th percentiles) for the observed number of ASVs in model 3. We used the fifth percentile of the observed number of ASVs as the reference level and estimated the corresponding HR and 95% CI for each specific value.

Missing values in covariates were assumed missing at random and imputed using the random forest imputation algorithm.32 10 complete datasets were generated and the results of these datasets were combined by established rules.33

We also conducted several sensitivity analyses (online supplemental method S4). All analyses were weighted by appropriate NHANES survey weights34 and performed using R V.4.2.2 between 5 December 2022 and 20 May 2023. All p values were two sided, and a p< 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Population characteristics
sec.p: A total of 8224 participants (unweighted: mean (SD) age, 42.0 (15.1) years; 4104 (49.9%) males, 4120 (50.1%) females; 3058 (37.2%) non-Hispanic white, 1960 (23.8%) non-Hispanic black, 2237 (27.2%) Hispanic, 969 (11.8%) other) who had valid data on the oral microbiome diversity and survival through 31 December 2019 were included in this study (table 1 and online supplemental table S1). Participants with a higher observed number of ASVs were more likely to be younger, male, poor, non-Hispanic black or Hispanic, uninsured and current smokers and less likely to have hypertension, diabetes and cancer history. The highest quartile of ASV number had the smallest proportion of participants who self-rated their general health as ‘excellent/very good’. For oral-health-related variables, participants with a higher ASV number were more likely to have poor self-rated oral health and periodontitis and less likely to use dental floss.

caption.title: Sociodemographic and medical characteristics according to the observed number of amplicon sequence variants in the study population

tr.td: Ratio of family income to poverty threshold
Days of flossing in a week

fn.p: Weighted by appropriate NHANES sample weight.
NHANESNational Health and Nutrition Examination Survey

sec.title: Oral microbiome diversity and all-cause mortality
sec.p: Through the end of 2019, the median (IQR) follow-up time was 108 (95–120) months and 429 (5.2%) deaths from all causes were identified. In the Kaplan-Meier plot, the lowest quartile of the ASV number had the worst overall survival, while the other three quartiles had comparable survival rates (figure 3).

In the overall population, we observed that a higher ASV number of the oral microbiome was significantly associated with reduced risks for all-cause mortality. Compared with the first quartile, all three higher quartiles demonstrated an inverse association with all-cause mortality in model 1 and model 2. When additionally adjusted for oral-health-related variables in model 3, the inverse associations of the third and fourth quartiles further strengthened. Specifically, in model 3, though the second quartile was non-significantly associated with reduced risks for all-cause mortality (HR=0.80, 95% CI: 0.60 to 1.08), the third quartile was significantly associated with a reduction of nearly 50% in mortality risk (HR=0.55, 95% CI: 0.37 to 0.82). Additionally, the fourth quartile, which exhibited no significant association in model 1 or model 2, was significantly associated with lower all-cause mortality risk in model 3 (HR=0.58, 95% CI: 0.38 to 0.89) (table 2).

caption.title: HR for association of observed number of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) in oral microbiome with all-cause mortality through the end of 2019 in Cox proportional hazard model

fn.p: Model 1 adjusted for basic demographic covariates, including age, race/ethnicity, and gender. Model 2 adjusted for socioeconomic and health-related covariates, including income-poverty ratio, health insurance status, body mass index (), smoking status, cancer history, hypertension, diabetes, and self-rated general health in addition to covariates in Mmodel 1. Model 3 adjusted for oral health -related covariates, including self-reported oral health and periodontitis in addition to covariates in Mmodel 2.

sec.p: We also analysed the distribution of the underlying leading causes of death according to the ASVs in the overall population (online supplemental table S2). Malignant neoplasms were the most common cause in all quartiles (accounting for 2.8%, 1.4%, 1.2% and 1.1% from the lowest quartile to highest quartile), heart diseases were the second (accounting for 1.6%, 1.0%, 0.7% and 1.1% from the lowest quartile to highest quartile). To elucidate the association between oral microbiome diversity and systemic diseases, we clarified details about the distribution of ASVs according to the status of health including hypertension, diabetes mellitus and self-rated general health (online supplemental tables S3 and S4). As for individuals with hypertension, the fractions decreased as increasing quartiles (32.2%, 24.0%, 23.4% and 20.4%), which was opposite to that in individuals without hypertension (22.4%, 25.4%, 25.6% and 26.6%). 34.3% of the people with diabetes mellitus were in the first quartile and 20.7% in the fourth quartile. The fractions in all quartiles of people without diabetes mellitus ranged from 24.0% to 25.5%. The distribution of ASV quartiles according to different self-rated general health status was relatively uniform in all quartiles (ranging from 20.5% to 29.8%).

sec.title: Stratified analysis
sec.p: In stratified analysis, we observed slightly different results between younger (age <50) and older (age ≥50) populations, but these results were generally consistent with those from the overall population. In the younger population (age <50), no significant associations were observed. However, the association direction suggested that a higher quartile of the ASV number be associated with a higher risk for all-cause mortality. Specifically, the association strengthened when the quartile of the ASV number increased. In model 3, the association of the second quartile was HR=0.83 (95% CI: 0.46 to 1.52), strengthened to HR=0.62 (95% CI: 0.33 to 1.18) for the third quartile and further to HR=0.41 (95% CI: 0.14 to 1.19) for the fourth quartile, although these associations were not significant.

In the older population (age ≥50), we observed that the third quartile of the ASV number was significantly associated with reduced risks for all-cause mortality in all models. The second and fourth quartiles demonstrated inverse associations with reduced mortality risk as well, though not significant. Compared with the first quartile of the ASV number, the second quartile was significantly associated with less all-cause mortality in model 1 (HR=0.66, 95% CI: 0.43 to 1.00) but weakened to non-significant in model 2 or model 3. By comparison, the third quartile was significantly associated with less all-cause mortality in all models (eg, in model 3: HR=0.52, 95% CI: 0.31 to 0.87). The association of the fourth quartile was close to null in model 1 or model 2 but strengthened to clear inverse association in model 3, though not significant (HR=0.73, 95% CI: 0.41 to 1.29) (table 2).

sec.title: Non-linear relationship
sec.p: Results from the non-linear spline models corroborated our observations from the Cox regression models that the all-cause mortality risk significantly decreased as the ASV number increased. A steep slope was observed for <120 ASVs, beyond which the reduced risk became steady (figure 4).

caption.title: HR for all-cause mortality according to the continuous number of the observed amplicon sequence variants in the oral microbiome. The reference level is set at the fifth percentile. The shading represents 95% CIs. Model adjusted for age, race/ethnicity, gender, income-poverty ratio, health insurance status, body mass index, smoking status, cancer history, hypertension, diabetes, self-rated general health, self-reported oral health and periodontitis.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: Results from our sensitivity analysis were consistent with the main analysis. The unconditional logistic regression (online supplemental table S5) and complete-case analysis (online supplemental table S6) corroborated that a larger number of ASVs was significantly associated with lower all-cause mortality risks in the overall as well as stratified populations. When considering other alpha-diversity metrics (online supplemental tables S7–S9 and figures S1 and S2), the higher value of these metrics, which represents higher oral microbiome diversity, was significantly associated with reduced risks for all-cause mortality. The Shannon-Weiner’s index shows the greatest sensitivity for the association, as it demonstrated the strongest association.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this cohort study using nationally representative data for US adults, we observed that a higher oral microbiome diversity was linked with greater socioeconomic disadvantages and poorer oral health. Despite these links, a higher oral microbiome diversity was significantly associated with a lower risk for all-cause mortality. Compared with the lowest quartile of oral microbiome diversity, the risk for all-cause mortality was reduced by nearly 50% in the highest quartile. These inverse associations were observed among both the younger (age <50) and older (age ≥50) populations. Overall, our study suggests that higher oral microbiome diversity can be beneficial for general health.

The oral microbiome plays a critical role in shaping oral health, and this relationship exhibits a unique pattern when compared with diseases and microbiota in other parts of the body. Chronic diseases associated with alterations in microbiota, such as inflammatory bowel disease, dermatitis and pneumonia, are mostly characterised by reduced diversity within the microbiome of their respective sites, leading them to be referred to as dysbiotic diseases.3537 In contrast to these dysbiotic diseases, oral disease demonstrates an increase in microbiome diversity.17 Additionally, the commensal species that contribute to oral health are typically retained rather than lost; however, they represent a smaller proportion of the overall community as microbiome diversity increases in the presence of oral disease.38 39 Our observations corroborate this unique pattern as we noticed poorer self-rated oral health and a higher prevalence of periodontitis in groups with higher quartiles of the ASV number. In this sense, a higher microbiome diversity is not preferred as it implies worse oral health.

The oral microbiome is recognised as a vital link between oral health and general health. Oral pathogens within the microbiome community can be transmitted to distant sites through the bloodstream, triggering systemic inflammation and ultimately contributing to the progression of other systemic diseases.6 40 Additionally, gastrointestinal colonisation by the oral microbiome can lead to dysbiosis and gut barrier dysfunction.41 Maintaining good oral hygiene is, therefore, crucial in controlling the overall burden of oral microorganisms.42 43 This has led to the recommendation of oral hygienic practices for the general population, which effectively inhibit the growth of oral micro-organisms and the accumulation of plaque biofilm. However, it is important to acknowledge that these oral hygienic practices entail additional economic expenses.44 Consequently, the prevalence of oral diseases tends to be higher among individuals of lower socioeconomic status who may struggle to afford these practices.45

All these pieces of evidence from the literature suggest that higher oral microbiome diversity not only indicates an increased risk for oral diseases but also reflects a lower socioeconomic status. Our observations align with these findings. We indeed observed that higher oral microbiome diversity was associated with several socioeconomic disadvantages, such as being a racial/ethnic minority, having lower household income, being uninsured, frequent smoking, as well as higher rates of periodontitis, poorer self-rated oral health and less floss usage. Interestingly, despite above correlations, it is surprising to observe that higher oral microbiome diversity was significantly associated with lower all-cause mortality risks. Importantly, this inverse association is robust and strong across different models, as evidenced by a nearly 50% reduction in mortality risk when comparing the higher quartiles with the lowest quartiles, indicating that it is unlikely to be attributed to chance. We also explored non-linear relationships, and the findings corroborated that higher diversity beyond a threshold was associated with lower mortality. To better understand the relationship between oral microbiome to mortality, we used three different models that adjust for known confounders, such as socioeconomic, health and oral health variables to mitigate potential bias, as outlined in the methods section. Results from the three different models suggest the robustness of our estimates.

Although we included confounding factors as much as possible, it was impossible to adjust for all confounding factors affecting all-cause mortality. Previous studies indicated great heterogeneity both in specific disease status and oral microbiome characteristics, which showed dynamic changes over time.46 47 Furthermore, the oral microbiome data is likely to be characterised during established health status and may be influenced by specific diseases or their causative factors. Changes in oral microbiome diversity are often considered a compensatory response to the development of disease.48 Medications, especially oral antibiotics, may reduce oral microbiome diversity and may confound the results. However, most diversity changes occur during the first 3–7 days of administration,49 50 but NHANES data did not provide detailed medication histories. It is worthy of note that further longitudinal studies with larger sample sizes, detailed self-reported information and dynamic data including oral microbiome and socioeconomic status are needed.

To investigate the association between oral microbiome diversity and systemic disease, we analysed the underlying leading cause of death and the distribution of ASVs according to the status of health. We found that two of the most common underlying leading causes of death were malignant neoplasms and heart diseases among all quartiles, and the fractions were higher in lower quartile than higher quartile. However, over 90% data about the cause of death was missing. Nearly one-third of the people with hypertension or diabetes mellitus were in the first quartile, and the fractions among all quartiles were relatively uniform in people without hypertension and diabetes mellitus or in people with different status of self-rated general health, ranging from 20.5% to 29.8%. The association between oral microbiome diversity and systemic disease was complex, we believe further studies are needed to elucidate the causal pathways between oral microbiome diversity and overall health outcomes, which could be addressed with more specific longitudinal health data.

These findings present a paradoxical situation regarding oral hygienic practices. One possible explanation is that excessive hygienic practices indiscriminately inhibit commensal species that are beneficial for general health. An illustrative example is the use of chlorhexidine-containing mouthwash and its impact on nitrate-reductase-expressing oral bacteria.5154 Clinical studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of chlorhexidine-containing mouthwashes in treating periodontitis, gingivitis and other oral diseases by inhibiting bacteria associated with these conditions.5558 However, chlorhexidine-containing mouthwashes also reduce the presence of Porphyromonas and Actinomyces which are responsible for nitrate synthesis in the oral cavity.59 60 These nitrates are essential for cardiovascular health. Research has shown that the use of chlorhexidine-containing mouthwashes leads to elevated blood pressure, with a more pronounced effect observed among individuals with hypertension.51 52 54 61

It is important to acknowledge that the beneficial effect of high oral microbiome diversity seems to reach a plateau once the diversity surpasses a certain threshold. In fact, the effect estimates in our models were comparable for the two highest quartiles. This observation is further supported by the findings from our spline model, which indicated that the risk for all-cause mortality stabilises beyond specific points. Therefore, a reasonable conclusion would be that only oral microbiome diversity below a certain threshold poses significant risks to health. This concept aligns with observations in other body sites in the literature, where the most consistent characteristic of microbial communities in diseased patients is a loss of taxonomic diversity.62

Building on findings from this study, it is reasonable to conclude that low diversity of the oral microbiome, rather than high diversity, should be a health concern, even though high oral diversity is linked with oral diseases, which provides new knowledge for the oral microbiome. While fully elucidating the clinical significance of the oral microbiome and mortality requires further research, this study serves as an important step in understanding from the population level and has important implications. First, oral microbiome diversity can be a reliable and valid indicator for general health, due to its strong association with all-cause mortality and also because this association overcomes confounding from socioeconomic factors. This means that individuals who are genuinely healthy, despite facing various socioeconomic disadvantages that impact their health, can still exhibit a high diversity of the oral microbiome, as observed in this study. Second, maintaining a high oral microbiome diversity can be healthy for human health. As most oral hygienic practices significantly reduce oral microbiome diversity, further investigations are necessary to reassess oral hygiene practices in the general population and ensure they do not lead to excessive practices.

This study is the first one to investigate the association between the oral microbiome diversity and all-cause mortality. It has several strengths. First, it stands out as a large-scale, nationwide and population-based study encompassing a follow-up period involving over 8000 participants who represent the broader population of the USA. In contrast, previous investigations on the oral microbiome were typically conducted with small, non-representative samples, limiting researchers’ ability to analyse its long-term impact on mortality.63 Second, our study effectively explores the relationship between oral microbiome diversity and various characteristics, including socioeconomic status, general health and oral health variables. This comprehensive approach illuminates the intricate nature of oral microbiome diversity and aids in mitigating potential confounding factors.

This study has several limitations. First, our focus primarily revolved around the overall alpha diversity of the oral microbiome and did not delve into specific species because data on specific species are not available at this moment. Second, it is important to recognise that there may be measurement errors in covariates such as socioeconomic status and medical history, as they relied on self-reported information obtained through surveys. Third, the oral microbiome data and self-reported information were collected at a single time point, preventing us from examining how microbiome diversity changes over time and how these changes influence individuals’ health. Overcoming this limitation necessitates further longitudinal studies with larger sample sizes and time-varying measures of the oral microbiome.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, among a prospective cohort that represents the US general population, we observed that higher oral microbiome diversity was significantly associated with a substantial reduction in all-cause mortality. Remarkably, this association persisted despite higher oral microbiome diversity being linked to greater socioeconomic disadvantages and poorer oral health. These findings indicate that high oral microbiome diversity is beneficial for overall health. Considering the potential health risks associated with low oral microbiome diversity and the fact that standard oral hygienic practices tend to reduce microbiome diversity, future research should reevaluate current oral hygiene recommendations to prevent excessive practices.

fn.p: Funding: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 82203292, 82203461).
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2024-087288).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

Ethics approval: This study involves human participants. The survey protocols were reviewed and approved by the Institutional Review Board of the National Centre for Health Statistics of the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) (protocol numbers: protocol #2005-06 (NHANES 2009-2010) and protocol #2011-17 (NHANES 2011-2012)). Participants gave informed consent to participate in the study before taking part. This study also received an ethical exemption from the Ethics Committee of the first Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University (approval number 2024136).

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: Data are available on reasonable request.
